Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Plasma-Platelet-RBC Ratios in Emergency Laparotomy

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised controlled trial involved severely injured patients

Participants.evidence: severely injured patients predicted to require massive transfusion at 12 level I North American trauma centers

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either a 1:1:1 or 1:1:2 ratio

Objective.evidence: We aimed to assess if this ratio improves survival after emergency laparotomy

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was survival at 24 hours and 30 days post-emergency laparotomy

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment ensured

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 680 patients were randomised, with 338 in the 1:1:1 group and 342 in the 1:1:2 group

Result_Outcome.evidence: The 24-hour survival was 86.8% for 1:1:1 and 83.1% for 1:1:2 (p=0.29), while 30-day survival was 79.3% for 1:1:1 and 75.0% for 1:1:2 (p=0.30)

Harms.evidence: No significant differences in adverse events were reported between groups
